question: He ferde feorr and wide geond middangeard - #### went far and wide throughout the earth
explanation: 'He' is the masculine third person singular nominative pronoun and translates to 'he'

question: Wisa, hwilc cræft þe geþuht betwux þas furðra wesan⁠ — Teacher, which craft do #### think is the greater?
explanation: Here 'þe' is the second person singular accusative pronoun and it translates to 'you'

question: Gif þin willa sie, wuldres aldor — If it be #### will, Prince of Glory
explanation: 'Þin' is the second person singular genitive pronoun and it translates to 'your'

question: Sæge, gif þu cunne, hwæt seo wiht sie — Say, if #### know, what that creature might be
explanation: 'Þu' is the second person singular nominative pronoun and it translates to 'you'

question: Ic wille þæt hie gode ðeawas sien — I wish that #### could be good slaves
explanation: Here 'hie' is a plural nominative pronoun and it translates to 'you'

question: Nu hie sceal þe meten — Now they shall meet ####
explanation: Here 'þe' is the second person singular accusative pronoun and it translates to 'you'

question: Se deofol gesette hine uppan ðæm scylfe ðæs heagan temples ⁠— The devil set #### upon the summit of the high temple
explanation: 'Hine' is the masculine third person singular accusative pronoun and it translates to 'him'

question: Ða axode heo hine hwæðer heo scolde þa næglæs mid hire læden — Then she asked him whether she should carry the nails with ####
explanation: Here the feminine third person singular pronoun 'hire' is being used in the dative and translates to 'her'

question: Ða behydde Adam hine ond his wif eac swa dyde — Then Adam hid #### and his wife also did so
explanation: Here the masculine pronoun 'hine' is used reflexively and so means 'himself'

commonMistakes.explanation: Here the masculine pronoun 'hine' is used reflexively and so means 'himself', not 'him'

question: He hire hand nam ond heo sona aras⁠ — He took #### hand and she arose at once
explanation: Here the feminine third person singular pronoun 'hire' is used in the genitive and translates to her

question: Heo hogde georne ðæt hire mægþhad clæne geheolde⁠ — She earnestly intended to keep #### maidenhood pure
explanation: Here the feminine third person singular pronoun 'hire' is used in the genitive and translates to her

question: We us gegadrian to his halgan gelaðunge, þæt ure naman beon awritene on lifes bec mid his gecorenum — We gather us to his holy congregation that #### names may be written in the book of life with his chosen
explanation: 'Ure' is a plural genitive pronoun and translates to 'our'

question: Ic bidde eow fliemaþ þa Peohtas! — I bid ####, expel the Picts!
explanation: Here 'eow' is a plural accusative pronoun and translates to the plural 'you'

question: Gif we eow ða gastlican sad sawaþ, hwonlic biþ ðæt we eower flaslican þing ripon — If we sow the spiritual seeds for you, it is little matter that we reaped #### fleshly goods
explanation: 'Eower' is a plural genitive pronoun and translates to 'your'

question: Ne mæg middaneard eow hatian ac he hataþ me⁠ — The world may not hate ####, but he hates me
explanation: Here 'eow' is a plural accusative pronoun and translates to the plural 'you'

question: Hie hæfdon hine mid him oþ ðæt hie ofslogon hine⁠ — They had him with #### until they slew him
explanation: Here the dative pronoun 'him' is plural so it translates to 'them'

commonMistakes.explanation: Here 'him' is plural so it translates to 'them', not 'him'. You can tell it is plural as the related nominative is 'hie'

question: Geata bearn ferde to him ond hie hine mid sweorde ofslean — The children of the Geats went to #### and they slew him with a sword
explanation: Here the dative pronoun 'him' is singular so it translates to 'him'

commonMistakes.explanation: Here 'him' is singular so it translates to 'him', not 'them'. You can tell 'him' is singular and not plural because of 'hine' in the second clause of the sentence

question: Hie spræc to hire ac seo fæmne nolde him andswarigen nan word — They spoke to her, but the woman did not want to answer #### with any words
explanation: Here the dative pronoun 'him' is plural so it translates to 'them'

commonMistakes.explanation: Here 'him' is plural so it translates to 'them', not 'him'. You can tell it is plural as the related nominative is 'hie'

question: On forewerdne morgen ic drife sceap mine to hira læse ond melce hie tweowa on dæg — In the morning I drive the sheep to #### pasture and milk them twice a day
explanation: 'Hira' is the third person genitive plural pronoun and translates to 'their'

question: Min sweord biþ min lif — My sword is #### life
explanation: 'Min' is the first person singular genitive pronoun and translates to 'my'

question: Ic towurpe mine bernu and ic wyrce maran bernu⁠ — I will tear down my barns and #### will build bigger barns
explanation: 'Ic' is the first person singular nominative pronoun and translates to 'I'

question: He me sealde ðæt betest hors⁠ — He gave #### the best horse
explanation: Here the first person singular pronoun 'me' is in the dative and translates to 'me'

question: Ne winne ge ongen ða ðe eow yfel doð — Strive #### not against those who do you wrong
explanation: 'Ge' is the nominative plural pronoun and translates to 'you'

question: Ðu neart dysig, ac þin bearn is dysig — You aren't foolish, but #### child is foolish
explanation: 'Þ' is the second person genitive singular pronoun and translates to 'your'

question: Hie þe hira lifes þurh lust brucon — They who spent #### lives in pleasure
explanation: 'Hira' is the third person genitive plural pronoun and translates to 'their'
